Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Formation of Ethnoracial Identity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the processes by which children of new groups integrate into American society. More specifically, it focuses on the individual and group-level identity-formation processes central to their incorporation. This study will expand knowledge of these fast-growing but little-studied groups, especially of how they are transitioning to new patterns of life. Findings will advance understanding of identity formation and inform policy makers and educators concerned with the adaptation of new groups, and workers both outside and inside the groups whose goal is to ease their transitions.

This study uses ethnographic observations and interviews with high school students and teachers in the Bronx and Brooklyn to explore their integration experiences and the identity-formation processes central to their incorporation. Semi-structured interviews will be conducted with 50 children from new groups plus, for comparison and contrast, 40 students from more established groups but generally matched on school performance and economic status. In addition, 20 teachers and staff will be interviewed. These interviews will be supplemented with ethnographic observations of classrooms, local recreation areas, and local commercial centers. The data and contrasting perspectives will illuminate how ethnoracial identity may be formed and changed in a diverse environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advances understanding about the processes by which the children of new immigrant groups integrate into American society, and the individual and group-level identity formation processes central to their incorporation. Methodologically, it draws on ethnographic observations and interviews with 127 West African immigrant youth, their Black American, West Indian, and Hispanic peers and teachers in New York City high schools.

The project has two theoretical contributions. First, there is relatively little research on the experiences of Black immigrants and their children, compared to other immigrant groups of color. Yet, Black immigrants are a fast growing population whose racialization has important consequences for their integration into American society. African immigrants in particular are recent newcomers whose population has experienced an almost 400% increase over the last four decades. This research remedies this gap by studying the integration experiences of African immigrant children. In doing so, it contributes to understandings about how the process of assimilation unfolds generationally across racial and ethnic lines. Findings reveal that families, local institutions (i.e. schools and neighborhoods), transnationalism and sociopolitical contexts significantly shape the integration of second-generation West African immigrants and the ways they understand their racial and ethnic identity. This research also provides empirical support showing that as immigrants and their host communities continually interact, a mutual cultural reconstitution process occurs that fundamentally transforms both immigrants and the cultural landscape from which host society communities fashion an "American" identity. A paper based on early analysis of these findings in this area, "Convergent Identities; Divergent Meanings: The Racial and Ethnic Identities of Second-Generation West African Youth" is published in African and Black Diaspora: An International Journal. A second paper is under review for publication in a peer review journal.

A second theoretical contribution of this project concerns racial dynamics in the U.S. Much of the mainstream discourse on the consequences of the United States' rapidly changing racial demographics exclusively focus on growths in the Hispanic and Asian populations. The implicit assumption is that Blackness is a relatively stable category. This research highlights how the arrival of African immigrants is redefining understandings of Blackness. I find that African immigrants are contributing to the nation's pool of ethnic and racial options, and through their relations with other groups, influencing how they and others understand their identities. Taken together, this work helps us better understand America's changing racial frame. 

By shedding light on how NYC's local policy and institutional contexts impact Black immigrants' incorporation, this project allows for policy recommendations that better appreciate the ways racism and anti-immigrant sentiments are mutually reinforcing in how they shape the experiences of Black immigrants. Moreover, this research point to avenues for improving social relations between racial and ethnic groups. For example, the co-PI's findings on the cultural exchange processes among West African and their Black American, Hispanic and West Indian peers suggests that educators and youth workers should focus on creating more opportunities for positive interaction that specifically center on the cultural elements around which there has been positive exchange.
